Input files

An explanation of the provided example input files can be found in Running HOwDI Example/Tutorial.

arcs.csv

Describes the arcs in the network and distance between them.

arcs.csv

startHub

endHub

kmLength_euclid

kmLength_road

exist_pipeline

Name of the first hub, as defined in hubs.csv

Name of the end hub

Distance between hubs in straightline distance

Distance that a road vehicle would travel between hubs

Is there an existing pipeline between these hubs?

Names should be in camelCase

Km

Km

Binary (1 or 0)

Example

example of arcs.csv

startHub

endHub

kmLength_euclid

kmLength_road

exist_pipeline

austin

waco

152.40950173410138

163.5097

0

dallas

houston

360.431235113376

384.3372

0

freeport

houston

89.06892475844474

99.1198

1

waco

houston

261.16592973831126

289.0303

0

waco

dallas

139.75266300122152

152.1352

0

austin

houston

235.69261123650796

261.8612

0

Relevance to model

  • The model index and set \(e \in E\) is the set of all edges/arcs. Regrettably, the model’s terminology is not consistent or established for this. The arcs.csv file describes all the edges/arcs that connect a hub to another, but, since a hub contains many nodes, there are many model edges connecting nodes within a hub and nodes that are in different hubs.

  • In create_network.py, costs associated with transportation are multiplied by the road distance between hubs to get costs per unit (pipeline, truck) that will be used as parameters in the model. The capital \(D_c(\delta)\) [1] and variable \(D_v(\delta)\) costs of pipelines are functions of road length. Only the variable cost of a truck route is multiplied by road length; capital costs are determined only by the number of trucks on the route.

  • Determines existing pipelines when constructing the network, which sets the capital cost of the pipeline to zero.

[1]

Fixed costs are calculated as a user-inputted fraction \(\kappa\) of the capital costs.

ccs.csv

Describes the carbon capture and storage (CCS) technologies that can be used to retrofit existing thermal hydrogen producers.

Note

This feature is not fully implemented yet. The currently supported types are ccs1 and ccs2.

ccs.csv

Header:

type (actual index)

variable_usdPerTonCO2

percent_CO2_captured

h2_tax_credit

Description:

Label of CCS retrofit type

Cost to capture a ton of CO2

Percentage/100 of CO2 captured by the CCS type

Tax credit for hydrogen cleaned by retrofit CCS

Units:

ccs1 or ccs2

$/ton CO2

0.00-1.00

$/ton H2

Example

example of ccs.csv

type

variable_usdPerTonCO2

percent_CO2_captured

h2_tax_credit

ccs1

50

0.6

459

ccs2

70

0.9

689

Relevance to model

  • type is \(\psi \in \Psi\) in the model formulation.

  • variable_usdPerTonCO2 is \(CCS_v(\psi)\), used here.

  • percent_CO2_captured is \(\beta(\psi)\), used here.

  • h2_tax_credit is \(\tau_{\text{H}_2}(\psi)\), used here.

Relevance to model

  • converter is \(\pi \in \Pi\) in the model framework.

  • variable_usdPerTon is \(C_v\), used here.

  • capital_usdTonPerDay is \(C_c\), used here.

  • kWh_perTon is \(C_e\), used here.

  • In the model, the convertor is placed between arc_start_class and arc_end_class.

  • utilization is \(\mu\), used here and here.

demand.csv

Describes demand sectors. The amount of of hydrogen consumed per demand sector at each hub is defined in hubs.csv.

demand.csv

Header

sector

breakevenPrice

carbonSensitive

avoided_emissions_tonsCO2_per_H2

demandType

Description

Chosen name given to demand sector

Maximum price consumers in this sector are willing to pay

Binary if H2 consumed must have equivalent clean H2 generation

Carbon emissions sector avoids by switching to H2

Type of demand

Units

name

$/metric ton H2

0 or 1

ton CO2/ton H2

(fuelStation, lowPurity, or HighPurity)

Example

example of demand.csv

sector

breakevenPrice

carbonSensitive

avoided_emissions_tonsCO2_per_H2

demandType

transportationFuel

4000

0

13

fuelStation

transportationFuel_carbonSensitive

5000

1

13

fuelStation

industrialFuel

5000

0

12

lowPurity

existing

5000

0

9

lowPurity

Relevance to model

  • sector corresponds to \(\xi \in \Xi\) in the model formulation.

  • breakevenPrice is \(U_{bp}\), used here.

  • carbonSensitive is \(S_{\text{CO}_2}\), used here.

  • avoided_emissions_tonsCO2_per_H2 is \(Q'_{\text{CO}_2}\), used here.

  • The model currently only supports fuelStation, lowPurity, and highPurity as demand sectors.

Relevance to model

  • The distributor column decides if the distribution method is a pipeline or a truck. This column refers to \(\delta \in \Delta\) in the model. The item pipeline is required, and only looks at other distribution methods that contain the word truck.

    Todo

    This should probably be changed based on unit, look at the code.

  • Consequently, the unit column is useless in the current version of the model.

  • capital_usdPerUnit is \(D_c\), used here.

  • fixed_usdPerUnitPerDay is not used since fixed costs are calculated as \(\kappa\) percent of capital costs.

    Todo

    Make sure that this is not used anywhere in the code and remove.

  • variable_usdPerUnit is \(D_v\), used here.

  • flowLimit_tonsPerDay is \(y_d^{\text{max}}\) used here.

hubs.csv

Describes hubs, which locations can build specific technologies, the amount of hydrogen demand that could be consumed at each hub, the local natural gas price, the local electricity price, and the local capital price multiplier.

hubs.csv

Header

hub

build_<producer1>

…

build_<producerN>

<demandSector1>_tonnesperday

…

<demandSectorN>_tonnesperday

ng_usd_per_mmbtu

e_usd_per_kwh

capital_pm

Description

Hub Name

Wether or not this hub can build <producer1>

…

Wether or not this hub can build <producerN>

Amount of demand in this hub in <demandSector1>

…

Amount of demand in this hub in <demandSectorN>

Local natural gas price

Local elecitricy price

Capital price multiplier

Units

0,1 (1=Can build)

…

Binary

tons H2/day

…

tons H2/day

$/MMBTU

$/kWh

Float near 1.00

Relevance to model

  • hub is \(\omega \in \Omega\) in the model formulation.

  • Replace <producer> in build_<producer> with the name of a producer \(\phi \in \Phi\). If there is not a column for each producer \(\phi \in \Phi\), the model will assume that the producer without a column can be built at any hub.

  • Replace <demandSector> in demand_<demandSector> with the name of a demand sector \(\xi \in \Xi\). The column corresponds to the model variable \(Q_{H_2}(\omega, \xi)\), used here.

  • ng_usd_per_mmbtu is \(\gamma(\omega)\), which is used to calculate thermal hydrogen production costs.

  • e_usd_per_kwh is \(\varepsilon(\omega)\), which is used to calculate electric hydrogen production costs and conversion costs.

  • capital_pm is \(\lambda(\omega)\), used in calculating all capital costs.

production_electric.csv

Describes prices and relevant information regarding carbon impacts of electricity production (electrolyzers).

production_electric.csv

Header

type

capEx_$_per_kW

kWh_perTon

variable_usdPerTon

utilization

purity

min_h2

max_h2

grid_intensity_tonsCO2_per_h2

Description

Name used to describe producer

Capital Expenses

Amount of electricity need to produce a ton of H2

Variable costs of production

Perctange of time utilized per time period/100

Purity of H2 produced

Minimum capacity size

Maximum capacity size

Tax credit for a new producer

Carbon grid intensity

Units

$/kW

kWh/ton H2

$/ton H2

(0.00-1.00) per (day)

“low” or “high”

tons H2/ day

tons H2/day

$ /ton H2 produced

tons CO2 produced / ton H2 produced

Example

example of production_electric.csv

type

fixed_usdPerTon

capEx_$_per_kW

kWh_perTon

grid_intensity_tonsCO2_per_h2

electrolyzer

50

50000

0

0.975

high

250

50000

600

3.6

electrolyzer-RE

50

720

50000

0

0.4

high

250

50000

3750

0

In this example, the electolyzer-RE (electrolyzer that uses renewable electricity) differs from the other electrolyzers in that the grid intensity is zero and the utilization is lower (representing the fact that renewable electricity is not always available). The electrolyzer that uses renewable electricity also gets a larger tax credit.

Relevance to model

Todo

As before, remove fixed costs of production?

  • type is \(\phi_{\text{electric}} \in \Phi_e \in \Phi\) in the model formulation.

  • The product of capEx_$_per_kW [2] and kWh_perTon is \(P_c(\phi_e)\), used here.

  • kWh_perTon is also used here.

  • variable_usdPerTon is \(P_v(\phi_e)\), used here.

  • utilization is \(\mu(\phi_e)\), used here.

  • purity determines how the producer is connected to the network.

  • min_h2 is \(y_p^{\text{min}}(\phi_e)\), used here.

  • max_h2 is \(y_p^{\text{max}}(\phi_e)\), used here.

  • h2_tax_credit is \(\tau_{\text{new}}(\phi_e)\), used here.

  • grid_intensity_tonsCO2_per_h2 is \(G(\phi_e)\), used here.

[2] (1,2)

I believe this is $/kW/day. There is a document somewhere that explains these units and how that ties into amortization.

Todo

Double check footnote [2] with Dr. Emily Beagle.

Relevance to model

  • type will match a type in production_thermal.csv. Corresponding data will be gathered from that row.

Todo

Figure out which data are used (good way to learn about the code) and remove unnecessary columns from this input file.

  • hub will match a hub in hubs.csv. The existing producer will be built at that hub.

  • capacity_tonPerDay is used here.

  • capital_usdPerTonPerDay is \(P_c\) used here.

Todo

Fixed costs

  • kWh_perTon is \(P_e\) used here.

  • ng_mmbtu_per_tonH2 is \(P_g\) used here.

  • variable_usdPerTon is \(P_v\) used here.

  • co2_emissions_per_h2_tons is \(B_{\text{exist}}\) used here and here.

  • can_ccs1 is \(\zeta_{CCS}(n_{p_{\text{exist}}})\) used here.

  • utilization is \(\mu\) used here.

settings.yml

  1. Price tracking settings

These settings control how the delivered price of hydrogen is determined. See price nodes for more information.

  • find_prices: if True, the model will find the price of hydrogen for each specified hub.

  • price_tracking_array

    • start : the lower bound of the price tracking array
